It is not, however, my de≈øign to enter into a general de≈øcription of fevers, and their differences; but merely to take notice of the epidemic which lately raged ≈øo univer≈øally in this city and its ≈øuburbs.

div.head: CHAPTER I.

div.p:
THIS di≈øea≈øe generally, in the fir≈øt place, affected the per≈øon with a ≈øen≈øe of chilline≈øs, alternating with gentle flu≈øhings‚Äîand a ≈øen≈øe of ≈øorene≈øs of all the mu≈øcles; the face appeared pale, the features ≈øhrunk, the body weary, as if it had undergone ≈øome great fatigue, attended with yawnings and ≈øtretchings of

About the third day, the inflammatory ≈øymptoms greatly changed, to tho≈øe of a putrid kind, or a remi≈ø≈øion of the fever took place: if the latter did not ≈øucceed, the tongue became dry, and began to be covered with a brown or black ≈øordes: not long after the teeth and lips put on the ≈øame appearance; re≈øpiration became more anxious, with an increa≈øed pro≈øtration of ≈øtrength: the vital functions at this time were much more di≈øturbed; watching, or a comato≈øe ≈øtate, now took place, if it had not before appeared; and even tho≈øe who did ≈øleep, enjoyed it but for a few moments, when they waked as if in a fright: the pul≈øe became ≈ømaller, weaker, and more frequent; thir≈øt was greatly increa≈øed; nau≈øea much more intolerable, together with the ≈øen≈øe of oppre≈ø≈øion at the ≈øtomach: tho≈øe who had not vomited before, had that direful ≈øymptom added now to the others: the contents of the ≈øtomach, which were thrown up in the act of vomiting, were generally of a fetid nature; the voice began to be changed; ≈ømall petechiae appeared about the neck and brea≈øt; when the body, and even the room, unle≈øs well ventulated, had a cadaverous ≈ømell‚ÄîThe patient kept continually rolling or turning in the bed, and frequently picking the bed-clothes. div.p:
IN cla≈ø≈øing di≈øea≈øes, it ≈øhould be our endeavour to reduce the genera and ≈øpecies to as limited a number as the nature of things will admit, ob≈øerving due per≈øpicuity in the definition of the complaint. div.p: PREDISPOSITION is that ≈øtate of the body not ≈øufficiently di≈øordered to con≈øtitute di≈øea≈øe,Brown's Elements of Medicine. but verging towards it, and rendering a per≈øon ≈øu≈øceptible to the operation of an occa≈øional or exciting cau≈øe, which are con≈øidered only as po≈ø≈øible cau≈øes.
